intro: Iodanthus mexicanus, commonly known as the Mexican iodine plant, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant produces small, yellow to orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are alternate, narrow, and often covered in fine hairs, and it thrives in well-drained soils. Iodanthus mexicanus is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a hardy species in dry climates.
